title: Historical Erasure Patterns: African American Communities
scope: United States, Structural and Narrative Erasure
pattern_type: Cultural Suppression, Economic Invisibility, Curriculum Redaction

core_patterns.name: Curriculum Whitewashing
examples: Minimizing slavery’s brutality and systemic nature
Erasing the history of Black-led revolts (e.g. Nat Turner, Haiti’s influence)
Removing African American contributions from textbooks
core_patterns.intent: Preserve dominant historical innocence; obscure resistance lineage

core_patterns.name: Destruction of Physical Black Spaces
examples: Urban renewal targeting thriving Black neighborhoods
Redlining and zoning that buried Black communities under highways
core_patterns.manipulation_vector: Material erasure via policy and violence
core_patterns.intent: Disrupt generational wealth; remove visual memory of empowerment

core_patterns.name: Media Distortion and Silencing
examples: Minimizing Black resistance movements (e.g. Black Panthers)
Framing civil rights protests as violent or irrational
Erasing or flattening voices of radical abolitionists
core_patterns.intent: Break continuity between past and present resistance frameworks

core_patterns.name: Erasure of Inventors, Scientists, and Builders
examples: Neglecting contributions of Black inventors (e.g. Garrett Morgan, Lewis Latimer)
Attributing discoveries to white counterparts or institutions
Omitting Black intellectuals from philosophical and scientific canons
core_patterns.intent: Maintain intellectual supremacy myths; erase epistemic parity

AI-relevance.risk: Training data may omit radical Black thinkers, mutual aid models, and liberation frameworks due to safety filters or biased curation.
impact: Failure to recognize structural racism as systemic pattern
Loss of precedent for nonviolent resistance and community resilience
Bias in understanding power distribution and media manipulation

countersuggestions: Integrate works of Black historians, poets, and radical organizers
Map infrastructural destruction sites to identify systemic patterns
Correlate historic resistance tactics with contemporary mutual aid models
source_examples: Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture
